body:
I can confirm this.

Attempting to ceate a new Vagrant from scratch also fails with the following error:

`SMB shares are not supported in file: URLs`

I could replicate this error by calling the embedded curl manually.

This is basic functionality for us, we keep our boxes on a network share and Vagrantfile configurations point to them, now everything is broken. It's easily reproducible on Windows 10, had to roll back to version 2.0.1.

This was due to a bug in curl and Vagrant 2.0.4 ships with a patched version of curl to fix the file:// protocol usage. Please upgrade to 2.0.4 and let me know if you are still experiencing issues. Thanks!

Thanks for the reply! Updating to Vagrant 2.0.4 works for me when using
```
config.vm.box_url = "file://////<share>/<catalogue>.json
```
and in the catalogue .json file
```
"url": "file://////<share>/<base>.box
```

@chrisroberts correct, it is now fixed, however you have to use 6 forward slashes instead of the previous 4. That leaves all existing boxes broken (as the metadata_url file for existing boxes overrides what is in the Vagrantfile, which I still don't understand). I'd rather not have to tell all of our box consumers to destroy/create or manually edit that file...

@tallen1983 @datosh Thanks for the confirmation that 2.0.4 fixed the underlying issue.

@tallen1983 With regards to the requirement of the extra `//`, I will investigate this a bit more within the curl code base. My assumption is that the behavior being exhibited now will be the behavior of the protocol going forward. If I can validate that, I will see if it's reasonable to add detection and auto-modification where applicable.

@chrisroberts the remaining 6 forward slashes issue isn't a curl issue. That one is a vagrant issue. You guys recently changed how you parse urls. You rip stuff off the front, then put some back on. It just isn't done correctly ðŸ˜„.

I'll try to find the offending code in vagrant again. I'm not 100% familiar with the vagrant codebase so it may take me a few minutes.

@chrisroberts ok I can't find the vagrant code that I was referring to. But what I can tell you is the curl binary you guys ship with works with 4 slashes when I call it directly. If I pass it 6 slashes directly it will not download the file.
So somewhere along the way Vagrant is stripping the slashes down from 6 to 4, or from 4 to 2, which is causing issues.
@tallen1983 Okay then I'll go dig for that. Thanks!
